review_blob: I dont have a lot of experience with English pale ales, so here goes. Color is dark clear gold with a white head that dissipates quickly. Taste is medium bitter on the front end, then a hint of pineapple?? toward the back of the tongue. Maybe pine. Body is light to medium; carbonation is has a nice bite; finish is bitter. I tend to like bitter beers more than sweet, so this one isnt bad. Overall, Id rate this beer pretty good, but I think Id rather load up my fridge with other varieties. Also, cool label.

I drank this one straight from the bottle so I cannot comment much on the color except to say that it was dark as expected. Flavor on the front end was sour and very much alcohol. Then WOW! first the coffee and then the chocolate flavors came alive. There was a nice heavy bitterness and a medium sweetness that seemed appropriate for both coffee and chocolate flavors. Nice chocolate finish that lingers. Do not make the mistake I once did, drinking this after ice cream, as the butter fat coats the tongue making this beer taste sour.

This dark amber beer had an aroma both familiar and un-namable. Taste was sweet and fruity on the front end, malty and tart with a medium, creamy body throughout the middle. It fills your head with alcohol all the way through the spectrum of flavors. Finishes clean. While I appreciate the complexity of this beer, I tend to like something more bitter than sweet. This beer left me feeling heavy and I struggled to finish it.
